@6:00 "Note that this only works for ionic bonds because the calculations requires the charges of the ions, which covalent bonds don't have" <-- this is wrong. Both covalent bonds and ion bonds work basically the same way (electrons making them attract to one another). There's no reason why a covalent bond can't have ions.

In fact, the definition of an ion is simply: "an atom or molecule with a net electric charge due to the loss or gain of one or more electrons". (first result from google)

A covalent bond is: " is a chemical bond that involves the sharing of electron pairs between atoms." (again, first result from google)

I find this channel extremely unhelpful to those who process auditory information more slowly or just not at all. It would help us; the viewers, if you could not only hold the frames with text, images, graphs, etc for more than 3 seconds. The expectation of someone to process this info in such a short amount of time is ridiculous and its not only this channel but its gotten into apps geared toward young adults like snapchat which in the news section of the articles only displays a frame that potentially has a lot of text for just a few seconds making making it so I have to go through 3 or 4 cycles just to finish reading it. So my final verdict is to highly recommend allowing +15 seconds to each frame with slower dialogue to increase the learning factor that your channel is trying to implement.

The units on the Cl2 energy diagram are wrong. The Cl-Cl bond length in Cl2 is 199 pm or 1.99 Å or 0.199 nm, NOT 0.00199 nm as stated. 0.00199 nm is 1.99E–12 m or 1.99 pm, which is 50 times smaller than a hydrogen atom.

I'm still wondering about the real reason atoms bound. I mean, at 2', CC says electrons are attracted to the protons of the other atoms. But why? That doesn't sound logic! I mean, there are also electrons on the other atom and they are even closer than the proton. So they should actually be repulsed by the electron(s) of the other atom because they are way closer than the proton is! In the case of hydrogen, imagine 2 balls with a negative shell and a positive charge in each middle. They would repulse each other, right?

I think you are mixing up the different ways to look at Coulomb's Law.
For Coulomb's Law:
F= (ke*q1*q2)/(r^2)

this is simliar to the gravitational force equation
F = (G*m1*m2)/(r^2)

Force is in Newtons.

When we walk over into chemistry land...
Modified Coulomb's Law for lattice energy:
E= (k*Q1*Q2)/(r)

Energy in joules.

I hope this helps.

There are a few parts of the video that are incorrect or not completely correct.  I just thought you would like to know about them.  First and most obvious would be the first showing of coulombs law.  The law shows that energy is proportional to 1/r^2.  This is corrected the second time the equation was shown.  The other parts lie in the introduction.  You mention that the electrostatic force arrises from each atom's electrons attracted to the other's protons.  This may be misleading as the attraction is only do to the electrons in an atom.  If a metal becomes an cation it has lost an electron, that "hole" is what attracts the anion.  It is correct that the net charge is due to the imbalance between the protons and the electrons in the cation and anion however, the way it was mentioned in the video could be misleading to those just learning chemistry. Aside from those comments I thought the video was very informative and well done.  I only bring the issues up because I had my students watch the video and saw some confusion as a result of the above issues.  Thank you so much.

You can tell this by the large difference in electronegativity of H and Cl.

If you go back and watch the CC episode on electrons, Hank explains how electrons reside in different energy states--shells contain subshells, which contain orbitals. Most atoms abide by either the octet or the duet rule. The principle for each remains the same: in order to gain maximum stability (lowest energetic state), an electron may be gained or lost to fill up or diminish the overflow of a shell. This is why the electrons don't re-transfer. :)

Oh, I forgot to mention this: the ionic bond definition given in general chemistry also assumes that it is a binary compound. Also, even Grignards involve ionic bonds. (R is any alkyl group, X is any halogen)
R−X + Mg → R−X•− + Mg•+
R−X•− → R• + X−
R• + Mg•+ → RMg+
RMg+ + X- → RMgX

Probably the cheapest chemistry textbook ever is the classic by Linus Pauling. It's a little intense and assumes that you have a pretty good math background and that you're serious about studying but it's quite thorough. Amazon sells it for about $14. All atom-atom bonds are simply energetically favorable interactions of non-zero time.  That holds whether they are hydrogen, covalent, van der waals, ionic or metallic.  
  What we define as molecules and the 'intermolecular' bonds that make them up are simply bonds with a relatively long lifetime.  "intermolecular' bonds are those that have shorter lifetimes and therefore don't form what we call stable molecules.  But in reality, it is a continuum, as liquid water shows us.

The term Hydrogen "bond" can be confusing b/c when we think of "bonding", we're thinking of INTRA-molecular bonds (between ATOMS. Ex: Between oxygen and hydrogen in a water molecule). In the case of hydrogen "bonding", this is a type of INTER-molecular bond (between MOLECULES. Ex: Between water molecules). They're NOT as strong as any intramolecular bond (such as a covalent bond) because of weak "orbital" overlap.
